metadata.title: A County-Level Susceptibility Index and Coronavirus Disease 2019 Mortality in the United States: A Socioecological Study

abstract.text: As of June 2020, the United States (US) has experienced the highest number of deaths related to 28 coronavirus disease 2019 in the world, but significant geographic heterogeneity exists at the 29 county-level. Therefore, we sought to classify counties in the United States across multiple domains 30 utilizing a socioecological framework and examine the association between these county-level groups 31 and Covid-19 mortality. We harmonized and linked county-level sociodemographic, health, and 32 environmental metrics associated with increased susceptibility for Covid-19 mortality. Latent class 33 analysis defined a county-level susceptibility index (CSI) based on these metrics (n=2701 counties). 34 Next, we used linear regression models to estimate the associations of the CSI and Covid-19 deaths per 35 capita and initial mortality doubling time (as of 6/2/20), adjusted for days since first Covid-19 case. We 36 identified 4 groups classified by the CSI with distinct sociodemographic, health, and environmental 37 profiles and widespread geographic dispersion. Covid-19 deaths per capita were significantly higher in 38 the group consisting of rural, vulnerable counties (55.8 [95% CI 50.3-61.2] deaths per 100,000) 39 compared with the group with diverse, urban counties (32.2 [27.3-37.0]) at similar points in the outbreak 40

body_text.text: Coronavirus disease 2019 is caused by a novel severe acute respiratory syndrome 44 coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV2) and has rapidly emerged into a global pandemic. While the first case was 45 documented to originate in China in November 2019 1,2 , Covid-19 is now widespread across the world 3-6 46 and in particular, has a very high burden in the United States (US) 7 . As of June 2020, the US has the highest number of deaths in the world due to Covid-19. While Covid-19 initially affected certain states 48 more heavily in the early period of spread including Washington 8 and New York 9 , Covid-19 outbreaks 49 have continued to emerge across the US with cases now reported in over 2,600 counties. To date, clinical and epidemiological data published from China, Italy, and in the US, reported higher 52 rates of symptomatic Covid-19 disease and severity among older adults. 1, 8 In addition to advanced age, 53 history of chronic lung or cardiovascular disease (CVD) are key risk factors of adverse outcomes such as 54 hospitalization and mortality related to severe Covid-19 infection. 10 Significant race-based disparities 11 In this study, we described a novel county-level classification scheme based on ecological factors that 119 may be associated with mortality burden related to Covid-19 that identified 4 distinct CSI groupings. 120 This classification scheme leveraged and integrated county-level metrics across multiple key domains 121 (sociodemographic, health-related, and environmental) from multiple data sources to distinguish patterns 122 in underlying county-level vulnerability and resilience. While there was a significant difference in early 123 mortality doubling time related to Covid-19, with faster doubling in diverse urban counties with greater 124 social assets, the burden of Covid-19 deaths per capita is significantly higher in rural counties with 125 social and medical vulnerabilities. The CSI classification scheme identified discordance in the early 126 slope or rapidity of spread within the first week and total loss of life per capita due to Covid-19. We 127 posit this discrimination is likely related to diverse urban counties representing the initial Covid-19 128 outbreak areas in the US, likely due to the high population density and more frequent international travel 129 in these coastal areas, with a later shift of burden towards the rural and vulnerable Southern counties. Our findings are consistent with recent data highlighting the "rural mortality penalty" that has emerged 132 in the US since the 1980's and has been widening in recent years. 24 This place-based health 133 disadvantage has been demonstrated for all-cause mortality as well as leading causes of 134 noncommunicable disease, such as cardiovascular disease and cancer, 25, 26 and likely reflects 135 convergence of multiple ecological factors related to social determinants of overall health, such as 136 income, education, and race. As spatial and temporal patterns of Covid-19 remain dynamic, the CSI 137 classification may inform location choices for future policy and intervention strategies to address the 138 burden of future waves, as the CSI scheme reflects differences in underlying vulnerabilities based on 139 social determinants of health in addition to comorbidity burdens and air pollution exposure at a 140 meaningful geographic scale (county-level). This is especially important given greater strain on already 141 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted July 6, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.07.04.20146084 doi: medRxiv preprint limited health resources, such as lower available intensive care unit beds per capita and access to 142 ventilators and hemodialysis machines in rural compared with urban areas. 27, 28 143 144 Data about the epidemiologic and clinical characteristics of Covid-19 positive patients to-date include 145 multiple studies highlighting the role of age as a major risk factor for disease severity and outcomes. In While 25% of hospitalized patients in the US were <50 years old, 85% of these younger adults had an 150 underlying condition. The most common underlying comorbidity was obesity (59%) followed by 151 chronic lung disease (36%), and diabetes (20%). Older adults were more likely to have underlying CVD 152 (51%) and hypertension (73%). Approximately 33% of patients were non-Hispanic black and 8% were 153 Hispanic. 12 Vulnerability as a result of underlying comorbidities may be one important factor in the 154 observed place-based disparities, but does not account for intrinsic systemic and structural racism within 155 our healthcare system that may also be contributing. 30 Our study incorporates both sociodemographic 156 factors and burden of chronic diseases at the county-level and provides a means to estimate suceptibility datasets to create a comprehensive classification scheme that integrates multiple county-level 165 characteristics across multiple domains.

Limitations of our analysis include potential misclassification of Covid-19 mortality data due to under-168 ascertainment of Covid-19 cases due to variable testing availability and resources across the US. 169 Further, we were not able to adjust for testing per capita at the county level as this information is only 170 available at the state-level. However, our analysis relied on the available comprehensive estimates of 171 cumulative Covid-19 mortality at the county-level and incorporated novel methodologic approaches.

Policy changes during the study period (e.g. social distancing, shelter-in-place) were heterogeneous 173 across counties and states and therefore were not adjusted for, but may have biased our results towards The findings from this current study provide unique insights into county-level characteristics that may 180 inform the lack of reserve or resilience at a population-level when challenged by an unexpected stress of 181 a highly infectious communicable disease that carries a significant risk of morbidity and mortality, such 182 as Covid-19. 17 The CSI classification scheme expands upon prior analyses by developing a simplified, 183 yet comprehensive classification scheme that benefits from the use of an unbiased methodologic 184 approach to include all relevant county-level characteristics across sociodemographic, health, and 185 environmental domains without penalty for high degree of correlations between several metrics. Other 186 tools, such as the social vulnerability index (SVI) and County Health Rankings (CHR) have been 187 applied in ecologic analyses for both health and non-health related outcomes. However, the SVI was 188 created by the CDC to inform responses to natural disasters and therefore relies only on demographic 189 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted July 6, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.07.04.20146084 doi: medRxiv preprint variables from the census and does not include health and healthcare access factors, which are integrally 190 related to community outcomes with Covid-19 exposure. 33 The CHR was developed in 2010 to stimulate 191 community efforts to improve overall health at the county-level, 34, 35 but only ranks counties within 192 states. Therefore, this current study extends prior reports by developing a national, comprehensive, and 193 data-driven classification scheme to reflect social and health vulnerability for the current pandemic as well as future communicable disease outbreaks on the county-level. 195 196 In conclusion, we develop an innovative county-level grouping scheme for counties that can be used to Table 1 ). For the first part of the analysis, we gathered relevant measures from these 213 sources to describe the counties according to the following categories: demographics, socioeconomic 214 All rights reserved. The inverse of the estimates of the county-specific slopes for time since first 240 report of 5 or more deaths became our secondary outcome. 251 We used latent class analysis (LCA) to classify US counties into groups based on the included metrics. 252 We included all counties for which we had complete ecological data across county-level metrics that The primary analysis, conducted in counties reporting both outcomes (N = 867 counties), consisted of 263 calculating the associations between CSI group assignment and each outcome described above using 264 All rights reserved. We fit two sets of models: 1) unadjusted and 2) adjusted for the time since the 265 first confirmed case in the county, to allow comparison between counties at similar points in their 266 outbreak. Point estimates were interpreted in context of their magnitude and Wald-style 95% confidence 267 interval.

We completed two additional analyses to explore the sensitivity of our estimates. First, to understand was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

It is not meant to infer causation; rather it is 176 meant to inform large-scale comparisons at the population-level to communicate with local health 177 departments and leaders to inform decisions at the county-level. 32 178 179

FIGREF5.text: 197inform equitable allocation of resources in places at-risk of greater burden of Covid-19 morbidity and 198 mortality to mitigate place-based health disadvantage related to Covid-19. It has now been well-199 described that Covid-19 related deaths are amplifying existing racial and geographic disparities at the 200 county-level.30 While widespread surveillance, contact-tracing, and immunity testing are urgently 201 needed and will ultimately be required for long-term recovery on the national level, these findings allow 202 for targeted mobilization at the county-level where the burden of Covid-19 per capita is 203 disproportionately greater in the near-term as the outbreak progresses spatiotemporally across the US.

FIGREF7.text: inconsistencies in the reporting of Covid-19 related deaths, some counties showed decreasing 243 cumulative death counts. To avoid negative estimates of doubling times, we applied the pool adjacent 244 violators algorithm 23 to the raw county-specific cumulative death counts to ensure they were 245 monotonically increasing prior to fitting the county specific linear regression model described above (N 246 = 34 counties). Counties whose estimated initial Covid-19 related mortality doubling time was 240 days 247 or longer were assigned a value from a single imputation from a uniform distribution with a minimum of 248 120 and maximum of 365 days (N = 157 counties).

FIGREF9.text: 253 span demographic, socioeconomic status, health status, healthcare access, and environmental factors 254 (N=2,701 counties). Groups of counties were assigned to a county-level susceptibility index (CSI) using 255 model-based predicted posterior probabilities. The LCA model incorporated binary and ordinal variables 256 as-is, and continuous variables were categorized as tertiles before inclusion. To select the optimal 257 number of classes (1-5) for the final LCA model, we imposed the following criteria: (1) qualitative 258 evaluation of distinct predicted classes or groups, (2) ensuring no group had fewer than 5% of counties, 259 and (3) minimizing the Bayesian information criterion. For each of the four final CSI groups, we 260 described county-level characteristics using means, medians, and proportions as appropriate.

FIGREF11.text: 270 whether our choice of analytic sample substantially affected the associations between CSI groups and 271 cumulative deaths per 100,000 persons, we repeated the primary analysis within all counties reporting 1 272 or more COVID-19 related fatality as of June 2, 2020 (N = 1735). Second, we evaluated the influence of 273 our selected starting point for estimating the associations between CSI groups and initial COVID-19-274 related mortality doubling time. We expanded our analytic sample to include any counties with at least 275 three days of reporting one or more cumulative deaths in the seven days following the first report of one 276 or more deaths in the county (N = 1,701 counties). As described above, we calculated the initial 277 COVID-19-related mortality doubling time beginning at the first report of any COVID-19 related 278 fatality, correcting data discrepancies as needed (987 counties), and repeated the primary analysis. All 279 analyses were completed using R version 3.6.3 or newer.
